Gas-phase benzoic acid hydrogenation is a promising strategy to produce benzaldehyde, but the formidable obstacle is the development of cost-effective and environmentally friendly catalysts. Herein, we carefully constructed the Y-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst, which achieved 92.1 % benzoic acid conversion and 92.7 % benzaldehyde selectivity and maintaining stable performance for over 200 h at 350 °C under atmospheric pressure. The structure-activity relationship revealed that the smaller and electron-rich ZnO particles were formed by the addition of yttrium oxides (YO x ), which facilitating the hydrogen dissociation and the formation of oxygen vacancies, thus promoting the conversion of benzoic acid. Moreover, the YO x also inhibited the overreduction of Zn2+ to Zn0 in ZnO, resulting in a significant reduction of the byproduct benzene to improve the selectivity of benzaldehyde. Finally, the reaction pathways of benzoic acid hydrogenation over Y-ZnO/Al2O3 were proposed based on experimental results in conjunction with characterization analysis. This work developed a cost-effective and environmentally friendly catalyst for the hydrogenation of benzoic acid to benzaldehyde and provided a theoretical insight of the structure-activity relationship. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Benzoic acid Hydrogenation Benzaldehyde Yttrium Oxygen vacancies Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Benzaldehyde (BAL) is an important chemical, which widely applied in various fields such as pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, perfumery, and fine chemical synthesis [1,2]. Various methods have been used to produce benzaldehyde in the laboratory or industry, including the halogenation of alkylaromatics followed by hydrolysis [3], halogenation of aromatic acids followed by hydrogenation (the so-called Rosenmund reduction) and oxidation of aromatic compounds alcohols or alkylaromatics [4,5]. However, those methods have serious drawbacks, such as low yield, environmental pollution, and the high cost of catalysts. In contrast, the direct gas-phase hydrogenation of benzoic acid(BA) offers a more efficient and sustainable approach to producing benzaldehyde because this method shows high atom utilization and environmentally friendly traits, making it well-suited in the industry [6]. As a result, significant research efforts have focused on developing catalysts with high activity, selectivity toward benzaldehyde, and robust stability to meet the requirement of industrial applications. The catalysts for gas-phase hydrogenation of benzoic acid to benzaldehyde are focused on metal oxides, mainly including ZrO2 [7], Y2O3 [7], ZnO [8], CeO2 [9] and MnO2 [10], where benzoic acid follows the reverse Mars-van and Krevelen (MvK) mechanism to produce benzaldehyde. Oxygen vacancies are regenerated by H2 reacts with the surface oxygen of oxides to release H2O, and then benzoic acid is deoxygenated on the oxygen vacancy to produce benzaldehyde [11]. This mechanism indicates that catalytic activity and selectivity of metal oxides for BA hydrogenation to BAL is decided by its ability to generate and sustain oxygen vacancies during reaction. Sakata et al. emphasized that the reducibility of catalyst is key factor to determine the product distribution during BA hydrogenation on oxides [12]. For instance, irreducibility oxides like MgO, PbO, Cr2O3, and La2O3 facilitate benzoic acid following a radical-like pathway to from benzene, toluene, and phenol. Moreover, highly reducible oxides like Fe2O3 and Co3O4 show low benzaldehyde selectivity and rapid catalyst deactivation due to the bulk reduction under operating conditions. Conversely, moderately reducible oxides, including ZrO₂, CeO₂, and ZnO, enable the selective deoxygenation of benzoic acid to benzaldehyde via the reverse Mvk pathway. The high benzaldehyde selectivity observed in ZrO2, CeO2, and ZnO is attributed to their strong metal-oxygen bonds (M-O), which can maintain moderate oxygen vacancies concentration under reaction conditions. However, the strong metal-oxygen bonds inevitably lead to high barrier energy to scission the M-O to form oxygen vacancies, thus limiting their catalytic activity and industrial application. To date, many efforts about enhancing the catalytic performance of ZrO2 and CeO2 have primarily focused on doping with low-valent metals [7,9,13]. This strategy can generate more oxygen vacancies by inducing charge imbalance to improving the catalytic activity [14]. However, few studies have reported improving the catalytic activity of ZnO for gas-phase hydrogenation of benzoic acid to benzaldehyde. In general, H2 dissociation is kinetically unfavorable and serves as the determining-rate step for the formation of oxygen vacancies on the oxide surface [15,16]. Moreover, promoting reactant absorption and stabilizing the reaction intermediates are also crucial to improve the catalytic activity [17]. It was accepted that the benzoates are reaction intermediates for benzoic acid hydrogenation on oxides, which are greatly related to the basicity of the catalyst because they are formed by dissociation absorption of benzoic acid [18,19]. As a result, improving H2 dissociation and the basicity of ZnO to create more oxygen vacancies and benzoates may be a feasible method to improve the catalytical activity of ZnO. Except for doping low-valent metals, the reducibility and basicity of ZnO can be simultaneously promoted by increasing the electron density of ZnO. For instance, Wang et al. demonstrated that the electron-rich ZnO achieved by electron transfer from ZrO2 to ZnO can accelerate H2 dissociation and improve the basicity of catalyst [20]. In this work, a series of Y-ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts were synthesized using a deposition-precipitation method. The addition of yttrium significantly enhanced the catalytic performance of ZnO/Al2O3. The conversion of benzoic acid and selectivity of benzaldehyde were achieved at 92.1 and 92.7 % respectively, and maintaining for 200 h with negligible deactivation under mild reaction conditions (350 °C and 1 atm). The reducibility and basicity of ZnO/Al2O3 were improved by the electron transfer between Y and Zn. Moreover, we demonstrated the benzene may formed at Zn0 sites over Y-ZnO/Al2O3 at lower temperature (350 °C) instead of the radical-like mechanism reported by previous work. Finally, the proposed reaction network and mechanism of benzoic acid hydrogenation over Y-ZnO-8/Al2O3 were elucidated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation All catalysts were synthesized via a deposition-precipitation method using Al₂O₃ as the support. Typically, 5 g of Al2O3 powder was dispersed in 100 ml deionized water and sonicated for 30 min to form the suspension. Then, a certain mixed solution, containing 0.5 M zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O) and 0.5 M yttrium nitrate hexahydrate (Y(NO3)3⋅6H2O), and 1 M ammonium carbonate (NH4CO3) were simultaneously dropped in the suspension under stirred at 70 °C, maintaining a pH of 7.5. After being aged for 2 h, the precipitate was filtered, washed with deionized water until the pH reached 7, and dried overnight at 110 °C. The dried precursor was then crushed, and calcined at 500 °C for 4 h in static air with a ramp rate of 5 °C /min. The resulting catalysts were denoted as Y-ZnO-x/Al2O3, where x represents the molar ratio Zn to Y. The loading of the active component (Y-ZnO) was fixed at 20 wt%. ZnO/Al2O3 and Y2O3/Al2O3 were prepared using the identical procedure as Y-ZnO-x/Al2O3. 2.2 Activity tests The catalytic activity tests were performed in a vapor-phase packed-bed reactor (I.D.= 8 mm), as shown in Scheme 1 . Typically 1 g of the catalyst (40–60 mesh) diluted by SiO2(the mass ratio of catalyst to SiO2 equals 1:3) was loaded into the tubular reactor. To ensure the catalyst was located in the constant-temperature zone, both ends of the reactor were packed with quartz sand and wool. The reaction temperature was monitored using a K-type thermocouple positioned at the center of the catalyst bed. Before the reaction, the catalysts were activated in situ with H2 (100 mL/min) at reaction temperature for 2 h. Subsequently, the liquid reactant, comprising benzoic acid dissolved in 1,4-dioxane, was pumped into the vaporizer from the bottom to the top at a controlled flow rate using a high-pressure liquid chromatography (HPLC) pump. The liquid reactant was vaporized and mixed with hydrogen steam in the vaporizer, and the resulting mixed vapor flowed into the reactor from top to bottom. The mixed reactant steam was preheated to the reaction temperature in a vaporizer before entering into the reactor. The outlet steam was condensed in a cold trap (273 K) and separated into two phases using a gas-liquid separator. The liquid products were collected every 12 h. After the reaction, the residual liquid in the pipeline was collected by sweeping with N2 for 2 h. The hydrogen flow rate was controlled by a mass flow controller (MFC). Catalytic performance was evaluated at varying contact times (W/F) by adjusting the catalyst mass in the range of 0.5–1.5 g. The contact times were defined as the ratio of the catalyst mass (kg) to the liquid feed molar flow rate (mmol/h) (Eq. (1)). 2.3 Products analysis The liquid products were analyzed by a gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and an Agilent DB-1701 column (30 m × 0.32 mm, I.D. = 0.5 μm). Nitrogen was used as the carrier gas at a partial pressure of 0.04 MPa. The injector and detector temperatures were set at 280 °C and 300 °C, respectively. The column temperature was programmed as follows: the initial temperature was set at 80 °C and maintained for 3 min, followed by increasing to 200 °C with a rate of 10 °C/min. The primary products of gas-phase hydrogenation of benzoic acid were benzaldehyde, benzyl alcohol, toluene, and benzene. Those products were qualitatively identified by matching their retention times with those of standard compounds. Quantitative analysis was performed using calibration cures prepared for each compound, with acetone as the internal standard. The conversion of benzoic acid was calculated as the number of moles of benzoic acid consumed divided by the initial number of moles of benzoic acid introduced into the reactor (Eq. (2)). The selectivity of each product (i) was determined as the number of moles of product (i) divided by the total number of moles of all products collected (Eq. (3)). Each set of evaluation data represents the average of two experimental replicates conducted under identical conditions. The carbon balance, based on benzoic acid, exceeded 95 % in all activity tests. (1) Contact times ( W / F ) = mass of catalyst liquid feed molar flow rate (2) Conversion ( % ) = ( 1 − mole of benzoic acid detected in GC mole of benzoic acid pumped ) × 100 % (3) Selectivity ( % ) = mole of product ( i ) ∑ mole of product ( i ) × 100 % Product(i) represents benzaldehyde, benzyl alcohol, toluene, and benzene, respectively. 2.4 Catalyst characterizations Detailed equipment information and operation parameters were recorded in supporting information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and surface chemical properties of catalysts The bulk phase structure of catalysts was identified by XRD. As shown in Fig. 1 . diffraction peaks at 37.6, 45.9, and 66.8° were observed in all samples, corresponding to the gamma Al2O3 [21]. Peaks at 31.7, 34.2, 36.2, 47.5, 56.6, 62.8, and 67.9° were assigned to the (100), (002), (101), (102), (110), (103), (112) facets of hexagonal ZnO, respectively [22]. The additive Y formed amorphous Y oxides (YO x ) as observed in the YO x /Al2O3, but YO x were not observed in the Y-ZnO/Al2O3 samples. The peak position of ZnO were unchanged in the ZnO/Al2O3 and Y-ZnO/Al2O3 samples, contributing to that Y3+was hardly doped into the ZnO lattice because the large difference of ionic radius between Y3+ (1.01 Å) and Zn2+ (0.74 Å) [23,24]. However, the intensity of ZnO peaks decreased in ZnO/Al2O3 and further in Y-ZnO/Al2O3, indicating the size of ZnO was reduced due to the dispersion of ZnO on the Al2O3 and the addition of YO x (Table S1, Fig. 1). The crystal size of ZnO decreased from 34.20 nm in ZnO to 13.46 nm in the ZnO/Al2O3, and further to 8.56 nm in Y-ZnO-8/Al2O3 (Table S1). Notably, diffraction peaks, such as at 56.6 and 62.8°, disappeared in the Y-ZnO-4/Al2O3 sample, indicating the significant structure distortion of ZnO at high Y content (Fig. 1b). Despite the crystal size of ZnO was reduced after the addition of YO x , the ZnO cell parameters were unchanged, corroborating that Y3+ions were not incorporated into the ZnO lattice. The phase structure of catalysts was further confirmed by HRTEM, as shown in Fig. 2 . Lattice spacings of 0.251, 0.261, and 0.280 nm were observed, which corresponding to (101), (002), and (100) planes of ZnO, respectively [25]. Amorphous YO x phases with discontinuous lattice fringes were also observed, which further confirm the Y formed amorphous Y oxides (YO x ) in Y-ZnO/Al2O3 and YO x /Al2O3 samples. ZnO exhibited discontinuous lattice fringes at Y-ZnO-4/Al2O3, indicating structural disruption of ZnO caused by the excessive addition of YO x (Fig. 2d). These TEM results were highly consistent with the XRD results. In addition, EDX elemental mapping revealed an even dispersion of Zn and Y in the Y-ZnO-8/Al2O3 sample (Fig. 2f-j). The chemical state and surface electronic information of Zn and Y were investigated by XPS. As depicted in Fig. 3 a, ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited a dominant peak at approximately 987.7 eV and a smaller peak at 991.0 eV in Zn LLM spectra, which corresponding to Zn2+ and Zn0 species, respectively [25]. The Zn Auger peaks were unchanged in Y-ZnO-4/Al2O3 compared to ZnO/Al2O3, but continually shifted to higher kinetic energy, from 987.6 to 987.9 eV, as the increased Y content. This shift suggested an increasing electronic density of Zn, where the electron-rich Zn species were represented as the Zn(2-δ)+ (0<δ<2). The Y 3d spectra were deconvoluted into two peaks at binding energy (BE) ranges of 159.7–160.2 and 157.1–158.1 eV, which were assigned to Y 3d 3/2 and Y 3d 5/2, respectively (Fig. 3b) [26]. Similarly, the BE values of Y 3d were consistent with those of YO x / Al2O3 in the Y-ZnO-4/Al2O3, but shifted to higher energies in Y-ZnO-8/Al2O3 and Y-ZnO-12/Al2O3, indicating a decreasing electronic density of Y. These results suggested that electron transfer from Y to Zn particularly at low Y loading, highlighting a significant electronic interaction between YO x and ZnO. The reducibility of catalysts was investigated by H2-TPR. As depicted in Fig. 3c, ZnO/Al2O3 showed a broad peak from 500 to 750 °C, which assigned to the reduction of ZnO [27]. In contrast, Y-ZnO/Al2O3 exhibited additional reduction peaks at 410–428 °C and 483–494 °C, which attributed to the reduction of Zn(2-δ)+ (0<δ<2) species due to these electron-rich Zn species facilitated H2 dissociation [20,28]. In addition, two prominent reduction peaks appeared at 557 °C and 670 °C in Y-ZnO-4/Al2O3, which attributing to the reduction of YO x , as confirmed by comparison with the YO x /Al2O3 sample. The small reduction peaks below 500 °C in the Y-ZnO-4/Al2O3 may be contributed to the reduction of ZnO with low crystallinity [14,22]. The quantity of reducible surface sites was estimated from the H2 uptake calculated from the H₂-TPR profiles up to 550 °C [29]. The H2 uptake increased from 17.0 mmol/g on ZnO/Al2O3 to 40.5 mmol/g on Y-ZnO-8/Al2O3, but decreased to 8.1 mmol/g on Y-ZnO-4/Al2O3 (Table 1 ). This suggested that the appropriate YO x promoted ZnO generated a substantial number of reducible sites. The ability to create oxygen vacancies in ZnO/Al2O3 and Y-ZnO-8/Al2O3 was investigated by EPR. As depicted in Fig. S1, the signal at a proportionality factor(g) of 2.003 corresponded to oxygen vacancies, and the concentration of oxygen vacancies was semi-quantified based on the intensity of this signal [30]. After the reduction, the signal intensity of Y-ZnO-8/Al2O3 were greater for ZnO/Al2O3, indicating higher concentration of oxygen vacancies in the former. This enhancement was ascribed to the improved reducibility of ZnO by the modification with YO x , as observed by H2-TPR results. CO2-TPD was carried out to evaluate the basicity of catalysts. In Fig. 3d, CO2 desorption signals in the low-temperature regions (< 200 °C) were assigned to physisorbed CO2 and weakly adsorbed species. In contrast, desorption signals above 200 °C attributed to chemisorbed CO2, which representing weak basic sites on the catalyst surface [31,32]. ZnO/Al2O3 and Y-ZnO/Al2O3 exhibited a main desorption peak centered at 300 °C, indicating their weak basicity. Conversely, YO x /Al2O3 showed two desorption peaks above 500 °C, characteristic of the strong basicity. The desorption peak at 557 °C observed in the Y-ZnO-4/Al2O3 sample originated from the YO x . Notably, the desorption peak position of ZnO/Al2O3 shifted to higher temperatures with increasing Y loading, indicating the strength of basicity of ZnO/Al2O3 was improved. Furthermore, the density of weak basic sites, calculated from CO₂-TPD profiles in the temperature range of 250–400 °C, also increased with Y loading, but showed a significant decline in the Y-ZnO-4/Al2O3 (Table 1). Those results suggested that the basicity of the ZnO/Al2O3 was enhanced by the incorporation of YO x , which could be attributed to electron transfer from YO x to ZnO, resulting in ZnO showed higher electron density and, consequently, higher Lewis basicity [20,33]. 3.2 The structure-performance relationship for Y-ZnO/Al2O3 The catalytic performances of ZnO/Al2O3, YO x /Al2O3 and Y-ZnO/Al2O3 for BA hydrogenation were investigated, as shown in Fig. 4 a. ZnO/Al2O3 exhibited limited activity, with BA conversion of 70.0 % and BAL selectivity of 66.7 %. In addition, YO x /Al2O3 demonstrated negligible BA conversion but achieved high BAL selectivity. In contrast, the catalytic performance of ZnO/Al2O3 was significantly enhanced by introducing YO x . Y-ZnO-8/Al2O3 achieved BA conversion of 92.1 % and BAL selectivity of 92.7 %. However, at higher Y loading, as in the Y-ZnO-4/Al2O3, the catalytic performance declined, falling below that of ZnO/Al2O3. This trend suggested that Y content is critical for enhancing both BA conversion and BAL selectivity of ZnO/Al2O3. Furthermore, Y-ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts yielded a single byproduct, benzene, while other byproducts, such as benzyl alcohol and toluene, were undetected. This simplified product distribution and the low boiling point of benzene (80 °C) facilitated the processes of BAL purification. Importantly, Y-ZnO-8/Al2O3 outperformed the majority of oxide-based catalysts reported in the literature and demonstrated catalytic performance comparable to commercial Cr/ZrO2 under low temperature conditions (350 °C) (Table S2). The structure-performance relationship of Y-ZnO/Al2O3 was elucidated based on experimental results and characterization analysis. Previous studies demonstrated that oxygen vacancies and benzoates are active sites and the reaction intermediates, respectively for hydrogenation of BA to BAL over ZnO [11,15,34]. The formation of oxygen vacancies and benzoate is related to the reducibility and basicity of the catalyst, respectively. Therefore, the correlations between BA conversion and H2 uptake (basic site density) were examined, as illustrated in Fig. 4b. The trend of BA conversion strongly correlated with H2 uptake and basic site density, which showed 0.97 and 0.86 correlation coefficient, respectively (Table 1). This result suggested the enhancement of BA conversion in Y-ZnO/Al2O3 was contributed to YO x promoted ZnO to produce more oxygen vacancies and benzoates intermediate. Moreover, BAL selectivity also increased in the Y-ZnO-8/Al2O3 catalyst by suppressing the formation of benzene. Previous studies have suggested that benzene can be generated via the thermal decomposition of surface benzoate at elevated temperatures for BA hydrogenation over oxides [11,35]. However, the benzene was observed at low temperature (350 °C), suggesting there are a distinct reaction pathway to form benzene in this study. Benzene was generated from the ZnO/Al2O3 instead of the YO x /Al2O3, as observed in Fig. 4a. Therefore, we hypothesized that benzene can be formed via the decarboxylation of BA at over-reduced sites, such as Zn0, on the ZnO surface because decarboxylation of oxygenates is easily carried out on the metal surface [36,37]. BA hydrogenation was performed over Zn powders under identical reaction conditions with ZnO/Al2O3 to further confirm this hypothesis. The results showed considerable benzene and toluene were formed for BA hydrogenation over Zn powders (Fig. 4c), consistent with the hypothesized role of Zn0 sites. Additionally, the relationship between benzene selectivity and the concentration of Zn0 ([Zn0]/[Zn0+Zn2+]%) were also examined, which demonstrated a strong correlation coefficient (R 2 = 0.97) (Fig. 4d and Table 1). Therefore, those results strongly supported the hypothesis that benzene primarily from at Zn0 sites on the ZnO surface. Consequently, the introduction of YO x into ZnO/Al₂O₃ not only enhanced oxygen vacancy formation and basic site density, but also suppressed the over-reduction of ZnO, thereby to promote the selective conversion of BA to BAL. 3.3 The proposed reaction mechanism and network The influence of reaction conditions, including reaction temperature (T), pressure (P), and contact times (W/F) for BA hydrogenation over the optimal Y-ZnO-8/Al2O3 catalyst, was thoroughly investigated to optimize performance and understand the reaction network. Fig. 5 a illustrates the influence of reaction temperature on BA conversion and product selectivity. BA conversion increased steadily with rising temperature from 310 °C to 390 °C, and achieving the complete BA conversion at 370 °C. This enhancement was attributed to the hydrogenation of BA to BAL is thermodynamically and kinetically favorable at elevated temperatures [38]. However, BAL selectivity remained high whem temperatures was below 350 °C, but declined sharply above 350 °C where the formation of toluene and benzyl alcohol became significant. The impact of reaction pressure on BA conversion and product selectivity was presented in Fig. 5b. BA conversion was improved as the pressure increased, reaching 99 % only at 0.1 MPa, which was attributed to enhanced surface coverage of BA under higher pressures [39]. However, BAL selectivity also declined significantly, dropping from 92.5 % to 68.6 % at 0.1 MPa, and further decreased to 52 % at 0.3 MPa due to the formation of toluene and benzyl alcohol. The impact of contact times (W/F) for hydrogenation of BA was shown in Fig. 5c. BA conversion increased gradually from 66.2 % to 99 % as the contact times increased from 1.01 to 1.42 kg/mmol·h. BAL selectivity remained high (>90 %) with benzene as the sole byproduct at shorter contact times, but declined markedly at longer contact times due to the formation of significant amounts of benzyl alcohol and toluene. This result suggested that BA conversion over Y-ZnO-8/Al2O3 follows a series of sequential steps, where BA is converted to BAL, which consecutively undergoes hydrogenation reaction to generate benzyl alcohol and toluene. The stability of Y-ZnO-8/ Al2O3 catalyst was evaluated under optimal reaction conditions (350 °C, 1 atm, and 1.3 kg/mmol·h). As shown in Fig. 5d, Y-ZnO-8/ Al2O3 catalyst demonstrated excellent stability, with no obvious deactivation in BA conversion and BAL selectivity over 200 h of continuous operation. Therefore, the advantages of low reaction temperature, superior catalytic activity and stability, cost efficiency, and environmentally friendly madeY-ZnO-8/ Al2O3 as a promising candidate for industrial-scale BA hydrogenation processes. Fig. 5a, b and c showed BAL selectivity was strongly dependent on BA conversion. BAL selectivity remained high at low BA conversion, while shapely decreased at high BA conversion due to the formation of benzyl alcohol and toluene, regardless of variations in T, P, and W/F. Haffad et al. demonstrated that BAL can be hydrogenated to toluene and benzyl alcohol over ZnO under H2 atmosphere at 300 °C [40]. Therefore, in this study, it was inferred that BAL can re-absorbed onto the surface of the Y-ZnO-8/ Al2O3 at high BA conversions to form toluene and benzyl alcohol byproducts. However, at low BA conversion, the reabsorption of BAL was suppressed due to the preferential adsorption of BA over BAL on the ZnO surface [35]. Additionally, the introduction of adsorptive inhibitors, such as CO2, also suppressed the formation of benzyl alcohol and toluene at elevated BA conversions. This suppression was attributed to the adsorption hierarchy of BA > CO2 > BAL on the surface of ZnO. CO2 also inhibited BAL re-adsorption and subsequent reactions. Therefore, BAL selectivity remained high at low BA conversion was contributed to BA effectively occupied active sites to prevent the transformation of BAL. The BAL selectivity was influenced by the formation of benzene at low BA conversion. At high BA conversion, Benzene selectivity was primarily affected by reaction temperature (Fig. 5a). As the temperature increased from 350 °C to 390 °C, benzene selectivity rose from 7.0 % to 20 %, which was attributed to the enhanced thermal decomposition of surface benzoates at elevated temperatures. Therefore, this result further demonstrated that benzene was produced flowing the distinct pathway at low temperatures (350 °C), probably generation by BA react at Zn0 sites as confirmed by Fig. 5(c) and (d). In conclusion, a proposed reaction network for BA hydrogenation over the Y-ZnO-8/Al2O3 catalyst at 350 °C was illustrated in Fig. 6 a. The formation of BAL and benzene proceeded through two parallel pathways involving different active sites. BAL was generated at oxygen vacancy sites (step 1), while benzene formation occurred at Zn0 sites (step 2). Benzyl alcohol and toluene were only produced via sequential reactions of BAL at elevated BA conversion (steps 3 and 4). The proposed reaction mechanism for the conversion of BA to BAL was depicted in Fig. 6b. Before the feeding of BA, the catalyst was pre-reduced under H₂ flow (100 mL/min) at the reaction temperature for 2 h to generate oxygen vacancies. This reduction process involved the activation of H2 and the subsequent cleavage of metal-oxygen bonds. H2 was heterolytically dissociated on Zn-O pairs, and the dissociated hydrogen atoms reacted with oxygen atoms to release H2O and generating oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface [41,42]. Upon introducing BA, bidentate benzoate intermediates were formed via the dissociative adsorption of BA molecules on Zn sites [7,43,18,44]. Subsequently, these bidentate benzoates were deoxygenated at oxygen vacancies to yield BAL, while simultaneously replenishing oxygen vacancies. The regeneration of oxygen vacancies was completed through the release of H2O again, ensuring the continuation of the catalytic cycle. In comparison with ZnO/Al2O3, Y-ZnO-8/Al2O3 catalyst demonstrated superior reducibility and basicity. These attributes promoted steps of the formation of oxygen vacancies and bidentate benzoate intermediates, thus facilitating the conversion of BA to BAL. 4 Conclusion In summary, this study constructed Y-ZnO-8/Al2O3 as a promising catalyst for the hydrogenation of BA to BAL under mild reaction conditions. Y-ZnO-8/Al2O3 catalyst achieved 92.1 % BA conversion and 92.7 % BAL selectivity, and showed exceptional stability over 200 h of continuous operation at 350 °C and 1 atm. Structural characterization revealed that the Y-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst consists of ZnO, YO x , and Al2O3 support. The introduction of YO x into ZnO/Al2O3 reduced the ZnO particle size and increased its electron density via electron transfer from YO x to ZnO, which enhanced H2 dissociation, oxygen vacancy formation, and the dissociative adsorption of BA. Moreover, the YO x also inhibited the overreduction of Zn2+ to Zn0 in ZnO, resulting in a significant reduction of the byproduct benzene to improve the selectivity of benzaldehyde. These synergistic effects contributed to the high catalytic activity and selectivity observed in Y-ZnO/Al2O3. The formation of BAL and benzene proceeded through two parallel pathways involving at oxygen vacancy sites and Zn0 sites, respectively. Benzyl alcohol and toluene were only produced via sequential reactions of BAL at elevated BA conversion, which can be suppressed at low BA conversions due to the preferential adsorption of BA on the catalyst surface. coredata.dc:description: Gas-phase benzoic acid hydrogenation is a promising strategy to produce benzaldehyde, but the formidable obstacle is the development of cost-effective and environmentally friendly catalysts. Herein, we carefully constructed the Y-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst, which achieved 92.1 % benzoic acid conversion and 92.7 % benzaldehyde selectivity and maintaining stable performance for over 200 h at 350 °C under atmospheric pressure. The structure-activity relationship revealed that the smaller and electron-rich ZnO particles were formed by the addition of yttrium oxides (YO x ), which facilitating the hydrogen dissociation and the formation of oxygen vacancies, thus promoting the conversion of benzoic acid. Moreover, the YO x also inhibited the overreduction of Zn2+ to Zn0 in ZnO, resulting in a significant reduction of the byproduct benzene to improve the selectivity of benzaldehyde. Finally, the reaction pathways of benzoic acid hydrogenation over Y-ZnO/Al2O3 were proposed based on experimental results in conjunction with characterization analysis. This work developed a cost-effective and environmentally friendly catalyst for the hydrogenation of benzoic acid to benzaldehyde and provided a theoretical insight of the structure-activity relationship.
